results.title: Couchman on customer service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Couchman over Australia”.
Couchman addresses the issue of the quality of customer service and asks how are we to survive in the competitive and cut-throat nineties. Examples of good and bad customer service are shown in a discussion about the tactics for enduring the recession.

results.title: Tattoos
results.creator_credit: Mark Bayly and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Couchman over Australia”.
Peter Couchman hosts a studio discussion on tattoos and why people wear them. He leads a debate on whether tattoos should be recognised as a legitimate art form. The audience is shown a tattoo being applied during the debate.

results.title: Mckenna's mind matters: control stress (S)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Paul McKenna’s easy way to health & fitness”.
WARNING: THIS VIDEO SHOULD BE KEPT OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN AND PERSONS UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE. THIS VIDEO SHOULD NOT BE WATCHED BY ANY PERSON WHO SUFFERS, OR MAY SUFFER FROM EPILEPSY, CLINICAL DEPRESSION, OR ANY OTHER NERVOUS OR PSYCHIATRIC CONDITION The Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria advises that this program contains outdated information, terminology and practices. The video “Control stress” will calm you down and preserve energy in order to reach goals. Using the latest techniques of personal enhancement, and hypnotic powers of trance to build up inner strength and peace.

results.title: Throwing
results.creator_credit: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Potter”
This film deals exclusively with the use of the potter’s wheel and explains the principles of centring. Various methods of making simple shapes such as a beaker or mug, a jug, a bowl, a dish and a bottle are also illustrated.

results.title: Pottery without a wheel. Parts. 1-3
results.creator_credit: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Potter: a series of films”.
The use of clay for the formation of useful objects such as tiles, trays and pots is discussed and demonstrated in this video which is specifically aimed at junior grades. Most of the examples are made with the assistance of students. These are treated in sequential order and degree of difficulty: Pottery without a wheel Part 1 - the use of coil pots are shown and made, the movement and rolling of clay as with the tools which are used for shaping and finishing are discussed. Pottery without a wheel Part 2 - the techniques of firing and finishing of the pots are shown. The making of tiles and other rolled objects are shown. Pottery without a wheel Part 3 - This discusses the firing and glazing of the finished pots and clay objects.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids

results.title: Australian women's archival Series
results.brief_description: Each year the Women’s Program of the Australian Film Commission produces an archival interview with a woman who has made a significant contribution to Australia during her lifetime.

group_works.title: Patsy Adam-Smith: author and social historian
group_works.creator_credit: Catherine South, Janet McLeod and Women's Program of the AFC

results.title: Patsy Adam-Smith: author and social historian
results.creator_credit: Catherine South, Janet McLeod and Women's Program of the AFC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian women’s archival Series”.
An archival interview in which Patsy tells of her childhood, the inspirations for her books, her philosophy on oral history, her working methods, the adventure of her life at sea and her thoughts on love, children and marriage. Most of her books focus on the lives of ‘ordinary’ Australian working people, uncovering the unique history, folklore and lifestyle - the ‘real’ history of Australia, often lost in the overview of traditional history. Tagged as an ‘unconventional woman’, Patsy ignored the social rules of her day, and blithely worked in, sought out and wrote about the worlds in which women traditionally had no place.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine South, Janet McLeod and Women’s Program of the AFC
